awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Directionally Aligned Macroporous Ceramics with In-Situ Synthesized Functional Polymer Microgels as a Platform for Next Generation Membrane Chromatography
awd_abstract_narration:
A monoclonal antibody is a protein capable of specifically binding a targeted molecule or receptor. Through this specific binding, antibodies become highly active drugs with reduced side effects. The market for biopharmaceuticals, such as monoclonal antibodies, is growing rapidly, with worldwide sales expected to reach $125 billion by 2020. The growing demand for antibodies and related biologics has driven up the cost of treatment using these products. As a result, the biopharmaceutical industry is increasingly under pressure from regulators, healthcare providers, and consumers to decrease production and treatment costs. Purification of monoclonal antibodies during bioprocessing is both slow and costly, representing more than 80% of the manufacturing expense. Membrane adsorbers are emerging as more efficient separation systems compared to conventional resin column beds in downstream biopharmaceutical manufacturing. Membrane adsorbers can be operated with much higher flow rates and throughput and, thus, are ideally suited for reducing processing times and production costs. The overarching goal of the EAGER project is to build the foundation for a new generation of macroporous membrane materials and modules that overcome the capacity, selectivity, and throughput limitations of existing commercial membrane adsorbers. To achieve this goal, functional polymers with high protein binding capacity and selectivity will be coupled with high surface area macroporous ceramic scaffolds, which can be configured into scalable modules for continuous bioprocessing. 

Within the biopharmaceutical manufacturing community, the desired transition to precisely targeted therapeutics based on monoclonal antibodies (mAb) depends on dramatically increasing manufacturing speed and reducing production costs. Although membrane chromatography has demonstrated advantages over standard column chromatography, including higher throughput and lower cost, it is limited by low protein binding capacity and selectivity of commercial membrane adsorbers as well as complex module configurations and fabrication. Consequently, there is a critical need for a new generation of membrane adsorber materials that can be readily configured into scalable modules with high binding capacity and selectivity. This project seeks to build a foundation for the next generation of scalable membrane adsorber materials and modules for downstream biopharmaceutical manufacturing that overcome the limitations of existing commercial membranes. This EAGER project will focus on achieving two specific objectives: the design, preparation, and characterization of 1) salt-tolerant membrane adsorbers with high protein binding capacity for mAb purification; and 2) membrane adsorbers for selective mAb capture and recovery from bioreactor harvests. The strategy to establish the foundation for these membrane adsorbers relies upon the design of a family of macroporous ceramics with tunable pore size, structure, and morphology using directional solution freeze casting. Building upon the porous scaffolds, a two-pronged approach will be undertaken. Firstly, in-situ polymerization and phase-separation micromolding will be employed to prepare functional polymer microgels inside macroporous ceramic scaffolds that contain high concentrations of ligands with large protein binding capacity and selectivity. Secondly, conformal microgel coatings of highly tortuous dendritic pores will be prepared to provide hydrodynamic trapping and adsorption sites inside macroporous scaffolds. Fundamental understanding of the material preparation and functionalization process and protein binding capacity and selectivity will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Membranes are semi-permeable barriers between two phases that allow selective transport from one phase to the other. Their inherent selectivity allows them to perform separations more energy efficiently than competing methods, such as resin chromatography. The improved energy efficiency and tailorable selectivity have facilitated the use of membranes in several fields including water purification, bioseparations, catalysis, and resource recovery. The mechanism of selectivity stems from both the membrane's physical structure and its chemical composition. As one example of an industry that requires the use of membranes, we focused on the pharmaceutical industry, where the monoclonal antibody therapeutic market is its fasted growing sector. Such antibodies can be used in the treatment of some forms of cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, and of recent interest, COVID-19. Processing of monoclonal antibodies requires an impurity removal step that currently accounts for 80% of the total manufacturing cost. These EAGER studies concentrated on a new generation of membrane adsorbers of monoclonal antibodies as they are purified, which would address the inefficiencies, and likewise, the cost of previous separation and membrane technologies. The work required advances in ceramic materials, macromolecular science and separation technology to establish membrane adsorbers of both high capacity and selectivity. 

Based upon knowledge of ceramic and polymer science along with separation technology, the foundations for a novel composite membrane adsorber comprising a macroporous ceramic scaffold and a mixed-matrix polymer for high binding capacity were established. The ceramic scaffold was designed to consist of a rigid, mechanically robust superstructure with cellular-like pore channels optimized for their size and shape. Such silicon oxycarbide scaffolds were developed using a freeze-casting technique, a scalable forming method that affords tunability in pore size, shape, spacing, and directionality.  The mixed-matrix polymer is situated in the pore channels and consists of functional polymer particles and a structural polymer, shown schematically in the accompanying figure. To our knowledge, no prior studies explored the use of mixed-matrix membrane compositions to fill pore channels. This combination of the ceramic scaffold and polymer matrix is advantageous because the ceramic scaffold can be designed to be chemically inert in bioprocessing conditions, readily functionalized to produce adherence between the ceramic and polymer matrix, and mechanically robust, particularly in contrast to porous polymer membranes. The novelty of the polymer matrix derives from functional polymeric microgels, for example, polyethylenimine, which are interwoven with an insoluble structural polymer, such as polyvinyl fluoride that maintains cohesion of the mixed matrix throughout the ceramic pore. The functional polymeric microgels swell in appropriate solvents and serve to bind species of interest, in this case, proteins in bioprocessing. Using a model protein, bovine serum albumin, binding experiments using the composite membranes demonstrated high static and dynamic binding capacity and show promise in the purification of monoclonal antibodies during bioprocessing.

US patent application (Serial number: 17/558,186) and PCT patent application (Serial number: PCT/US2021/064680), Functional Composite Membranes for Chromatography and Catalysis, describing the technology that evolved from the EAGER grant were filed on December 22, 2021.

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2022
Modified by: Katherine T Faber

Image
  • Schematic cut-away of one element in the composite membrane. Grey represents the ceramic macropore walls surrounding the polymer channel, orange, the functional polymers, and blue, the structural polymers. In bioprocessing, fluid would flow through mixed-matrix polymer channels for purification.
    Orland Bateman
    Copyrighted
    Katherine T Faber
    Composite membrane schematic
